title: AB 2514
content: The people of California enact the following. Section 34171 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to define terms related to administrative budget and administrative cost allowance for successor agencies. The administrative cost allowance for successor agencies is defined as the maximum amount of administrative costs that can be paid from the Redevelopment Property Tax Trust Fund. It is set at 5% of property tax allocated for the period January 1, 2012, through June 30, 2012, and up to 3% for each fiscal year ending on June 30, 2016. The allowance cannot be less than $250,000 unless reduced by the oversight board or by agreement with the successor agency. Starting July 1, 2016, the administrative cost allowance for successor agencies is up to 3% of the property tax distributed in the previous fiscal year. The minimum allowance is $250,000 unless reduced by the oversight board or by agreement with the department. Starting July 1, 2016, a successor agency's annual administrative costs cannot exceed 50% of the total Redevelopment Property Tax Trust Fund distributed to pay enforceable obligations in the previous fiscal year. This limit applies regardless of whether the costs are paid within the administrative cost allowance or not, but excludes costs paid from bond proceeds or grant funds. The administrative cost allowance is the sole funding source for legal expenses related to civil actions. Employee costs for project implementation activities are not considered administrative costs. "Designated local authority" refers to a public entity formed under specific sections. An "enforceable obligation" includes certain defined criteria. The "designated local authority" is a public entity formed under specific sections. An "enforceable obligation" includes bonds issued with required debt service and reserve set-asides. Loans borrowed by the redevelopment agency for lawful purposes must be repaid according to a required schedule. Payments to the federal government, state obligations, and federal base reuse obligations for the former Norton Air Force Base are also required. The county auditor-controller makes passthrough payments and legally enforceable payments for agencies' employees, including pension payments and obligations from collective bargaining agreements. Layoff or termination costs for city employees who worked for the former redevelopment agency are considered enforceable obligations payable from property tax funds. Employee obligations remain payable if transferred to the entity assuming housing functions. The successor agency or designated local authority must reimburse the housing entity for any employee obligations if the employee is transferred to the entity assuming housing functions. The oversight board, along with the successor agency, has the authority to appeal judgments or settlements against the former redevelopment agency. They can also terminate agreements or contracts with approval and provide compensation if needed. Titles or headings in documents do not determine enforceable obligations. Contracts or agreements necessary for the administration or operation of the successor agency, including litigation expenses, settlements, office space, equipment, supplies, and insurance costs, shall be paid out of the administrative cost allowance starting January 1, 2016. A sponsoring entity may provide funds to a successor agency for legal expenses related to civil actions. If the successor agency wins the case, the funds are repayable. If not, the funds are considered a grant. Repayments owed to the Low and Moderate Income Housing Fund of a redevelopment agency must be approved by the oversight board and transferred to the Low and Moderate Income Housing Asset Fund for affordable housing purposes. The curr_chunk discusses the criteria for an "enforceable obligation" in relation to agreements between the city and former redevelopment agencies. Written agreements for indebtedness obligations issued before specific dates may be considered enforceable obligations. Loan repayments to the Low and Moderate Income Housing Fund must be approved by the oversight board for affordable housing purposes. The curr_chunk discusses the criteria for an "enforceable obligation" in relation to agreements between the city and former redevelopment agencies. Loan agreements and agreements related to state highway infrastructure improvements may be deemed enforceable obligations. The curr_chunk discusses the enforceable obligations related to agreements between the city and former redevelopment agencies, specifically regarding repayment of loans or fulfillment of development obligations imposed by federal agencies. Contracts or agreements between former redevelopment agencies and public agencies for services or funding outside of redevelopment project areas not properly authorized under Section 33000 are void, except for housing-related contracts. The curr_chunk defines "Indebtedness obligations" as bonds or other debt issued by the redevelopment agency, "Oversight board" as entities established under Section 34179, and "Recognized obligation" as listed in the Recognized Obligation Payment Schedule. The curr_chunk further defines "Recognized Obligation Payment Schedule" as the document outlining minimum payment amounts for enforceable obligations, "School entity" as defined in the Revenue and Taxation Code, and "Successor agency" as the entity replacing the former redevelopment agency. The curr_chunk defines "Taxing entities" as cities, counties, special districts, and school entities receiving property tax payments. "Property taxes" encompass all tax revenues, and the "Sponsoring entity" authorizes redevelopment agency creation. The curr_chunk defines the "Department" as the Department of Finance, the "Sponsoring entity" as the entity authorizing redevelopment agency creation, and the "Final judicial determination" as a court decision not further appealed. From July 1, 2014, to July 1, 2018, the "housing entity administrative cost allowance" is up to 1% of property tax allocated to the Redevelopment Obligation Retirement Fund. The housing entity administrative cost allowance is remitted by the successor agency to the local housing authority that assumed the housing functions of the former redevelopment agency on January 2 and July 1, as listed on the Recognized Obligation Payment Schedule. If there are insufficient funds in the Redevelopment Obligations Retirement Fund, the unpaid amount can be carried over to future Recognized Obligation Payment Schedules without a five-year limit.
